body:
Hm, could you kindly paste a reference to the parameters you mentioned?

I just looked in `statsmodels`, and here is the list of parameters I could find.
The list does not include `smoothing_level`, `smoothing_trend`, or `smoothing_seasonal`.

```
        endog,
        trend=None,
        damped_trend=False,
        seasonal=None,
        seasonal_periods=None,
        initialization_method=None,  # Future: 'estimated',
        initial_level=None,
        initial_trend=None,
        initial_seasonal=None,
        use_boxcox=None,
        bounds=None,
        dates=None,
        freq=None,
        missing="none",
```

They have been mentioned in their tutorial notebook: https://github.com/statsmodels/statsmodels/blob/main/examples/python/exponential_smoothing.py

These three parameters are called while fitting the model and not while initialising it. The below image shows a snippet from the code in the above link.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/96042791/148554304-640caa45-3e79-4378-a978-1759f5b6d098.png)
Ohhhh, it's passed to `fit` and not to the constructor! Thanks!

We overlooked these, since they were being passed to `fit` in `statsmodels`. Bit of a questionable design decision on the side of `statsmodels` to pass some parameters in the constructor, and some in `fit`...

Aaaanyway, I've marked this a good first issue, since it should be only a few lines of code to add/change. I've also updated the issue at the top, with an instruction of what to do.

Thanks for bringing this to our attention, @ishannangia001. Feel free to add yourself as a contributor with an "ideas" contribution if you want to.

Agreed. Though I would imagine that the intuition might have been to keep iteratively testing out fits with different smoothing parameters for the same type of models as that might help in deciding the final smoothing parameters through cross-validation, etc.

Great. Thanks a lot ! Will certainly do.

>Though I would imagine that the intuition might have been to keep iteratively testing out fits with different smoothing parameters for the same type of models as that might help in deciding the final smoothing parameters through cross-validation, etc.

Sure - you can do this using a layer of tuning on top of the model, with `ForecastingGridSearchCV` from `sktime` ... as long as the ETS model exposes the parameters.

issue.title: [ENH] add missing `fit` parameters to `statsmodels` Holt-Winters exponential smoothing interface

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds parameters of `statsmodels.tsa.holtwinters` in `fit` as loopthrough to `sktime`'s `ExponentialSmoothing` interface.

So far, only the constructor parameters were accessible, not the parameters in `fit`.

Solves #1845.

body:
Done here now #1849 - I just went and added all parameters from `fit`.
Would be great if you could check if this is what you want (check out the PR branch and try).

Do you know what else would be great, @ishannangia001?

If you had the time to go through the various `statsmodels` interfaces and check whether we are missing any parameters. A list would already be useful; or, PRs per individual estimator that adds those parameters, given that you have proven that you know how to make a valid pull request :-) (see here #1848). You can take #1849 as a blueprint for changing estimators and get the "code" contribution badge!

issue.title: [ENH] `statsmodels` interfaces may be missing parameters - investigate and/or add them

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
In issue #1845, an instance of a `statsmodels` interfacing estimator was discovered which was missing crucial parameters.

The reason was that in `statsmodels`, model parameteres are spread out across constructor (`__init__`), `fit`, and potentially other functions.

Due to this, it would be important to look at other `statsmodels` interfaces to check whether we are missing useful parameters from non-constructor methods.

If we are, a notice here would already be useful. Further, these should be added to the constructor (not `fit` etc) of the corresponding `sktime` interface. A "blueprint" PR to carry out this addition of parameters is #1849 (for Holt-Winters smoothing).

body: I opened an issue here to collect and address missing `statsmodels` parameters: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1850

Perhaps, someone should also fix the apostrophe catastrophe in `statsmodels`' docstring.

E.g., someone should go and say "apologie's, you're docstrings' apostrophes' misplaced, its Peter Winter's"

> 

Can definitely try this out. Will keep working on different statsmodel estimators as and when I get time.
@ishannangia001, FYI, 0.10.0 is now released which has the smoothing parameters. Enjoy!
Thanks so much for this quick update ! Helps tons @fkiraly
